discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
VNet1 only - the question is singular "which virtual network" so there should only be one.

A. VNet1 only
Explanation:
To use your own network and provision Microsoft Entra hybrid joined Cloud PCs, you must meet the above requirements, and the following requirements:

The Azure virtual network must be able to resolve DNS entries for your Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) environment. To support this resolution, define your AD DS DNS servers as the DNS servers for the virtual network.
The Azure vNet must have network access to an enterprise domain controller, either in Azure or on-premises.
Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-365/enterprise/requirements-network?tabs=enterprise%2Cent

Selected Answer: A
-You must have a vNET in the same region as where the Cloud PC desktops are created." 
-The Azure vNet must have network access to a domain controller, either in Azure or on-premises.

Read here : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-365/enterprise/requirements-network?tabs=enterprise%2Cent

Selected Answer: A
A Seems Correct

comments.content: How do you know that cloud PC will be deployed in VNET2, this information is not included in the context of the question.

discussion.content:
To create an Azure network connection (ANC) for Microsoft Entra hybrid join, you need to ensure that the virtual network where the domain controller is located (dc1.contoso.com) is connected to the virtual network where the Windows 365 Enterprise Cloud PCs will be deployed.

Looking at the provided information:

The domain controller (dc1.contoso.com) is in VNet1.
The Cloud PCs will be deployed in VNet2.
Therefore, you should use:

D. VNet1 and VNet2

This option ensures that the virtual network where the domain controller is located (VNet1) is connected to the virtual network where the Cloud PCs will be deployed (VNet2), allowing for the necessary communication for Microsoft Entra hybrid join.

DRAG DROP

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

The subscription contains Android Enterprise devices that are enrolled in Intune and have personally-owned work profiles. All the Android devices are members of a group named Group1.

You need to ensure that end users and Intune administrators receive an email message when an Android device does NOT have an up-to-date security provider.

Which actions should you perform from the Microsoft Intune admin center in sequence? To answer, drag the appropriate actions to the correct order. Each action may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
correct, the notification message template needs to be created first

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/actions-for-noncompliance#available-actions-for-noncompliance

discussion.content: I think correct but in the wrong order. First you need to create the notification, and then you create the compliance policy where you add the notification message that you created before
Creating message template is first step!

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.

You have 25 Microsoft Surface Hub devices that you plan to manage by using Microsoft Intune.

You need to configure the devices to meet the following requirements:

• Enable Windows Hello for Business.
• Configure Microsoft Defender SmartScreen to block users from running unverified files.

Which profile type template should you use for each requirement? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
1. To enable Windows Hello for Business = Identity protection
2. To configure Microsoft Defender SmartScreen to block users from running unverified files = Device restrictions (Windows 10 Team).

The Identity protection template allows you to configure Windows Hello for Business settings, including enabling the feature and setting up various authentication options.
The Device restrictions (Windows 10 Team) template is specifically designed for Surface Hub devices and includes options to configure Microsoft Defender SmartScreen settings, such as preventing users from bypassing SmartScreen prompts for unverified files.
Correct. SmartScreen has also been moved to Endpoint Security --> ASR (Attack Surface Reduction) --> Application Control.

Nevermind my previous comment about SmartScreen. ASR has an option for enabling SmartScreen, but Device --> Configuration Profile --> Endpoint Protection has it too. My guess is that Microsoft eventually moves those features over to Endpoint Security 1 day. They did the same with Windows Hello for Business.

discussion.content:
Identity procation is now renamed to Account protection
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/identity-protection-configure

I am not sure how the first one is correct. The only place where I can found WHFB settings are in Intune > Endpoint Security > Account Protection > Account Protection Policy. 
There is no "identity protection" template for Windows 10 or higher in Configuration profiles.

Answer are correct: 

Group 1: Device 3
Group 2: Device 1, Device 2 and Device 3
Group 3: Device 1

Scope for the policy:
Include: group 2
Exclude: Group 1 and Group 3

So: 
N: Device 1 has the extension attribute1 "Test" that will make member of group 3 which is excluded of the feature update deployment profile

Y: group 2 members are running windows, Device 2 will be part of the feature update deployment profile

N: Device 3 is part of the group 1 which is excluded from the feature update deployment profile
